description.narrative: Core Humanitarian Standard, evidence-based and that meets needs holistically by integrating a triple nexus approach. This model will be peer-reviewed by other experts in the Global South. Once further funding is secured, it will become operational, with multiple organizations making varied, layered contributions to common outcomes according to their strengths # to ensure humanitarian responses uphold interwoven development and peace objectives and are thereby sustainable and transformative. Additionally, the platform willproduce a robust operating procedure for its Anticipatory Response Fund, which serves as an emergency response mechanism/crisis modifier. Many INGOs, including Oxfam in Myanmar and Bangladesh, have successfully piloted this response mechanism with local partners.Upon request by local partners, the Somalia Joint Response is also piloting this mechanism with local partners in 2020, and all SOMJR INGOs have included a crisis modifier in their budgets in 2020. The Anticipatory Response Fund serves as a means for local humanitarian partners to quickly access funding to respond to sudden crises and emergencies. The fund's aim is to address funding gaps andensure quick access to emergency funding for local responders. The fund will build oncurrent initiatives in country to promote local humanitarian leadership and preparedness, and deliver on commitments made in the Grand Bargain and Charter for Change by donor andNGO signatories. It will also identify strengths and areas for capacity development in relation to emergency response in Somalia The operating procedure for the Anticipatory Response Fund will include triggers and related protocols, such that a pilot test of triggers, collaboration mechanisms and protocols can take place ahead ofthe humanitarian response windows, in the second half of 2020. Beyond the pilot phase, these actions will lay the foundations for a response mechanism that is pre-emptive and therefore efficient and highly responsive # improving the quality of locally-led humanitarian response in Somalia and Somaliland. Delivering on the ambition statement (i.e. development of above-mentioned model for humanitarian programming and operating procedures) will contribute to all four DRA strategic priorities: 1) more effective support for locally-led responses by supporting Nexus as locally-led platform; 2) innovation and learning by generating knowledge outputs and new ways of working; 3) collaboration for increased effectiveness by bringing together a wide range of localactors with coverage of all 9 regions of Somalia and Somaliland; and 4) more accountable humanitarian action by giving voice and decision making power to local organisations and adding rigor through South-South peer review.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.
